text:
Using the ant bundled w/Eclipse 3.0 M3 (v1.5.4) on Mac OS X 10.2, environment variables seem to 
be ignored and interpreted as literal strings. For example:

<property environment="env"/>
...
<echo message="JBOSS_HOME is set to = ${env.JBOSS_HOME}"/>

should print (on my box)...

"JBOSS_HOME is set to = /usr/local/jboss"

instead it prints...

"JBOSS_HOME is set to = ${env.JBOSS_HOME}"

What you are trying to do 

1. what does   <echoproperties/> say

2. what does running with -verbose say

3. please post your whole build file. Maybe the target dependencies are wrong

4. what does ant on the command line do? It may be an artifact of eclipse
integration

text: And MacOS X is a Unix and therefore casesensitive ...
creator: jan@materne.de
bodewig@apache.org
text:
I just tried it (10.2.8 here) and it works for PATH.

So there probably is something wrong with your build file (or JBOSS_HOME is not
set in the environment that runs Ant).

I tried PATH and it produced the system default PATH. So I don't believe this is a bug anymore. 
This seems to be an artifact of the way GUI applications (such as Eclipse) pick up environment 
variables on OS X, or possibly a bug in Eclipse itself... in any event, it's probably not a problem 
within ant.

Thanks for taking a look at it.
